title: Why fascism is so tempting— and how your data could power it - Yuval Noah Harari

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between nationalism and fascism?

options.label: A
options.text: Nationalism is based on the idea of a single, supreme nation, while fascism is based on the idea of a unique identity.

options.label: B
options.text: Nationalism is based on the idea of a unique identity, while fascism is based on the idea of a single, supreme nation.

options.label: C
options.text: Nationalism is based on the idea of cooperation and mutual respect, while fascism is based on the idea of a single, supreme nation.

options.label: D
options.text: Nationalism is based on the idea of a single, supreme nation, while fascism is based on the idea of cooperation and mutual respect.

multiple-choice.question: According to Yuval Noah Harari, what is the main danger facing liberal democracy in the 21st century?

options.label: A
options.text: The rise of authoritarian regimes

options.label: B
options.text: The concentration of power in the hands of governments

options.label: C
options.text: The concentration of data in the hands of governments or corporations

options.label: D
options.text: The decline of nationalism

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between a fascist and a nationalist, according to Yuval Noah Harari?

options.label: A
options.text: A fascist is someone who prioritizes the interests of the nation above all else, while a nationalist is someone who prioritizes the interests of the nation along with other identities.

options.label: B
options.text: A fascist is someone who prioritizes the interests of the nation along with other identities, while a nationalist is someone who prioritizes the interests of the nation above all else.

options.label: C
options.text: A fascist is someone who prioritizes the interests of the nation, while a nationalist is someone who prioritizes the interests of the individual.

options.label: D
options.text: A fascist is someone who prioritizes the interests of the individual, while a nationalist is someone who prioritizes the interests of the nation.

multiple-choice.question: According to Yuval Noah Harari, what is the main advantage of authoritarian regimes in the 21st century?

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Their ability to control the flow of information

options.label: D
options.text: Their ability to make decisions quickly

multiple-choice.question: What is the main concern that Yuval Noah Harari has about the rise of artificial intelligence and genetic engineering?

options.label: A
options.text: That they will lead to the decline of nationalism

options.label: B
options.text: That they will lead to the concentration of power in the hands of governments

options.label: C
options.text: That they will lead to the concentration of data in the hands of governments or corporations

options.label: D
options.text: That they will lead to humanity becoming gods

title: The big-beaked, rock-munching fish that protect coral reefs - Mike Gil

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary role of parrotfish in coral reef ecosystems?

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: They are the main predators of coral polyps.

options.label: D
options.text: They are the primary competitors of coral polyps for space.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: They are a form of communication between coral polyps.

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: They have increased the number of coral polyps.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: Newton’s three-body problem explained - Fabio Pacucci

multiple-choice.question: What is the main issue with trying to find a general solution for the motion of three or more gravitating objects in the solar system?

options.label: B
options.text: There are too many unknown variables in the system.

options.label: C
options.text: The equations of motion are too complex to solve.

options.label: D
options.text: The gravitational force acting between bodies is too weak.

options.label: B
options.text: The gravitational constraint

options.label: C
options.text: The chaotic behavior

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: It is a method of calculating the gravitational force between two bodies.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: The gravitational force acting between bodies would increase.

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: The solar system would remain unchanged.

multiple-choice.question: A company's meatless burgers have been linked to three deaths after a poison was injected into the product. The police have concluded that a criminal targeted the brand. options.label: B
options.text: More customers could die if the killer poisoned packages elsewhere.

options.label: C
options.text: The company will save money on recalls.

options.label: B
options.text: Pulling and destroying products from all stores in the city.

options.label: C
options.text: Pulling and destroying products worldwide.

options.text: The company was fined heavily by the government.

options.label: D
options.text: The company's reputation was severely damaged.

options.text: They are deleted from the brain

title: The race to decode a mysterious language - Susan Lupack

multiple-choice.question: Who was the British archaeologist that uncovered nearly 3,000 tablets inscribed with strange symbols on the island of Crete in the early 1900s?

options.label: A
options.text: Alice Kober

options.label: B
options.text: Sir Arthur Evans

options.label: C
options.text: Michael Ventris

options.label: D
options.text: Lev Vygotsky

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the script that Sir Arthur Evans dubbed, which he thought represented the Minoan language?

options.label: A
options.text: Linear A

options.label: B
options.text: Linear B

options.label: C
options.text: Cypriot script

options.label: D
options.text: Minoan script

multiple-choice.question: What was Alice Kober's contribution to deciphering Linear B, despite her untimely death in 1950?

options.label: A
options.text: She discovered that Linear B relied on word endings to give its sentences grammar.

options.label: B
options.text: She deciphered the entire script in a single year.

options.label: C
options.text: She found that the script was a syllabary.

options.label: D
options.text: She built a chart of the relations between the signs.

multiple-choice.question: What was Michael Ventris' breakthrough in deciphering Linear B?

options.label: A
options.text: He compared the tablets from Pylos with those from Knossos and saw that certain words appeared on tablets from one site but not the other.

options.label: B
options.text: He deciphered the entire script in a single day.

options.label: C
options.text: He found that the script was a syllabary.

options.label: D
options.text: He discovered that the language of Linear B was not Minoan, but Greek.

multiple-choice.question: What remains a mystery to this day?

options.label: A
options.text: The deciphering of Linear B

options.label: B
options.text: The meaning of the Cypriot script

options.label: C
options.text: The actual language of the Minoans, represented by Linear A

options.label: D
options.text: The discovery of the Minoan script

title: Volcanic eruption explained - Steven Anderson

multiple-choice.question: What triggered the eruption of the volcano Paricutin in Mexico?

options.label: A
options.text: A decrease in magmastatic pressure

options.label: B
options.text: An increase in magmastatic pressure

options.label: C
options.text: A decrease in lithostatic pressure

options.label: D
options.text: A change in the Earth's crust

multiple-choice.question: What is the process called when magma begins to cool and some of the dissolved gases are left behind?

options.label: A
options.text: Hydrothermal alteration

options.label: B
options.text: Magmastatic pressure

options.label: C
options.text: Lithostatic pressure

options.label: D
options.text: Crystallization

multiple-choice.question: What is the process called when the weight of the rock above a magma chamber becomes dangerously low, triggering an eruption?

options.label: A
options.text: Unloading

options.label: B
options.text: Hydrothermal alteration

options.label: C
options.text: Magmastatic pressure

options.label: D
options.text: Lithostatic pressure

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the formation of high-pressure gas bubbles in magma?

options.label: A
options.text: A decrease in the magma's density

options.label: B
options.text: An increase in the magma's density

options.label: C
options.text: A decrease in the buoyant force pushing upward through the crust

options.label: D
options.text: An increase in the buoyant force pushing upward through the crust

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the challenges faced by volcanologists in predicting eruptions?

options.label: A
options.text: Measuring the strength and weight of the Earth's crust

options.label: B
options.text: Measuring the depth and heat of magma chambers

options.label: C
options.text: Measuring changes in magmastatic pressure

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

title: Inside the bizarre world of internet trolls and propagandists - Andrew Marantz

multiple-choice.question: According to the author, what is the main driver of conversation online?

options.label: A
options.text: Facts

options.label: B
options.text: Emotion

options.label: C
options.text: Logic

options.label: D
options.text: Reason

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between "smart skepticism" and "dumb skepticism"?

options.label: A
options.text: Smart skepticism is when you question every claim, and dumb skepticism is when you don't question anything.

options.label: B
options.text: Smart skepticism is when you are a contrarian, and dumb skepticism is when you are not.

options.label: C
options.text: Smart skepticism is when you question every claim, and dumb skepticism is when you don't question claims that you disagree with.

options.label: D
options.text: Smart skepticism is when you are a jerk, and dumb skepticism is when you are not.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's suggestion for social media companies to fix their platforms?

options.label: A
options.text: They should optimize for maximum emotional engagement.

options.label: B
options.text: They should optimize for something else, such as decency and human decency.

options.label: C
options.text: They should not fix their platforms at all.

options.label: D
options.text: They should only fix their platforms for some people, not for everyone.

multiple-choice.question: According to the author, what is the danger of the utopian and dystopian views of the internet?

options.label: A
options.text: They are both true.

options.label: B
options.text: They are both false.

options.label: C
options.text: They are both too simplistic and let people off the hook.

options.label: D
options.text: They are both equally bad.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's message about the future of the internet?

options.label: A
options.text: It will inevitably save us.

options.label: B
options.text: It will inevitably destroy us.

options.label: C
options.text: It is up to us to make decisions and shape the future of the internet.

options.label: D
options.text: It is too vast and complex to be all good or all bad.

title: Prohibition: Banning alcohol was a bad idea... - Rod Phillips

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary reason for the Prohibition in the United States in 1920?

options.label: A
options.text: To reduce poverty and domestic violence

options.label: B
options.text: To ban the production and sale of alcohol

options.label: C
options.text: To reduce the influence of organized crime

options.label: D
options.text: To increase tax revenue from alcohol sales

multiple-choice.question: Which groups were active participants in the temperance movements in the United States?

options.label: A
options.text: Only women's organizations

options.label: B
options.text: Only religious authorities

options.label: C
options.text: Women's organizations, religious authorities, and progressive labor activists

options.label: D
options.text: None of the above

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the Volstead Act, which took effect in 1921?

options.label: A
options.text: It banned personal consumption of alcohol

options.label: B
options.text: It allowed the manufacture and sale of alcohol to continue

options.label: C
options.text: It led to the closure of distilleries, breweries, and wineries

options.label: D
options.text: It increased tax revenue from alcohol sales

multiple-choice.question: What was the effect of the government's requirement to add harmful chemicals to industrial alcohol during Prohibition?

options.label: A
options.text: It reduced the number of poisoning deaths

options.label: B
options.text: It increased the tax revenue from alcohol sales

options.label: C
options.text: It led to thousands of poisoning deaths

options.label: D
options.text: It had no effect on poisoning deaths

multiple-choice.question: Why did the government repeal the 18th Amendment in 1933?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it was a success in reducing crime and social problems

options.label: B
options.text: Because it was a failure in reducing crime and social problems

options.label: C
options.text: Because it was a financial burden on the government

options.label: D
options.text: Because it was a result of the Great Depression

title: Can you solve the Ragnarok riddle? - Dan Finkel

multiple-choice.question: What is the task that needs to be accomplished in the scenario described in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Destroying a giant, but still living, snake.

options.label: B
options.text: Creating a path to destroy a giant, but still living, snake.

options.label: C
options.text: Running along the body of a giant, but still living, snake.

options.label: D
options.text: Using a hammer to hit a giant, but still living, snake.

multiple-choice.question: What mathematical object is described in the transcript as a tool for solving the problem?

options.label: A
options.text: A graph, or network.

options.label: B
options.text: A tree, or network.

options.label: C
options.text: A matrix, or network.

options.label: D
options.text: A set, or network.

multiple-choice.question: What is a key property of the nodes in the graph, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Every node has an odd number of edges emerging from it.

options.label: B
options.text: Every node has an even number of edges emerging from it, except two.

options.label: C
options.text: Every node has a fixed number of edges emerging from it.

options.label: D
options.text: Every node has a variable number of edges emerging from it.

multiple-choice.question: What is the goal of the runner in the scenario described in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: To run along the entire body of the snake as quickly as possible.

options.label: B
options.text: To destroy every part of the snake's body before it regenerates.

options.label: C
options.text: To hold the hammer high and wait for Odin to strike the snake.

options.label: D
options.text: To find the shortest path to the end of the snake's body.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the two nodes in the graph that have an odd number of edges emerging from them?

options.label: A
options.text: They are the only nodes that can be entered or exited twice.

options.label: B
options.text: They are the only nodes that can be entered or exited only once.

options.label: C
options.text: They are the start and end points of the path.

options.label: D
options.text: They are the nodes that must be visited twice to complete the path.

multiple-choice.question: What was the narrator's initial reaction to hearing about the new baby?

options.text: A: They were excited to meet the baby.

options.label: B
options.text: They were worried about the baby's arrival.

options.label: C
options.text: They were uninterested in the baby.

options.label: D
options.text: They were scared of the baby.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: C

title: A day in the life of a teenage samurai - Constantine N. Vaporis

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Miyamoto Musashi

options.label: C
options.text: The daimyo

options.label: D
options.text: The shogun

options.label: A
options.text: Miyamoto Musashi

options.label: B
options.text: Mori Banshirô

options.label: C
options.text: The daimyo

options.label: D
options.text: The shogun

multiple-choice.question: Why does Mori Banshirô's father initially refuse to take him to Edo?

options.label: A
options.text: Because Mori Banshirô is still in training

options.label: B
options.text: Because Mori Banshirô wants to pursue his artistic ambitions

options.label: C

options.text: Because Mori Banshirô's father is not confident in his son's abilities

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the daishô, a pair of swords that Mori Banshirô received at 15?

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: Eleanor

options.label: C
options.text: Maui

options.label: D
options.text: Harper

options.label: B

options.label: C
